text: Hi, I am Francis, the host of this show, Cooking with Dog.
Okay, let's have her chop the whole onion into rough pieces.
Make cuts like the spokes of the wheel, and leave the root attached.
Rotate the onion and make cuts perpendicular to the first cuts.
Next, let's cut the half onion into one-inch pieces.
Cut the onion into six wedges.
Make three cuts perpendicular to the first cuts.
Cut off the stem end of the eggplant and trim off the cap.
Partially peel the eggplant in a striped pattern.
Roughly chop it into rolling wedges.
Cut the bell pepper in half.
Remove the seeds from inside.
Chop it into one-inch pieces.
Remove the peel from the apple.
Soak the apple into salt water.
Grate the carrot coarsely.
Grate the garlic,
and grate the ginger.
Take out the curry block from the package.
Chop it into fine pieces.
Okay, let's fry the ingredients for curry.
Add olive oil in a saucepan.
Add the coarsely-chopped onion and fry for five minutes at high heat.
Reduce the heat and stir continually to avoid scorching.
Fry the onion for 10 minutes and make it golden brown.
Add the coarsely-grated carrot.
Fry two or three more minutes.
Add the grated garlic and ginger, and stir until aromatic.
Add curry powder and braise for two or three minutes at a low heat.
Add the eggplant and onion.
Stir until the mixture is coated with oil.
Add the canned tomato and water.
Crumble the soup stock cube.
Strip the dried bay leaf in half, and add it to the mixture.
Simmer away about ten minutes at a low heat.
Turn off the stove and add the chopped curry block.
Stir lightly and dissolve the curry block.
Grate the apple into a saucepan.
Add the bell pepper and turn on the stove.
Put the lid on again.
Stir from the bottom to avoid scorching.
Simmer a couple more minutes at a low heat until the bell pepper gets soft.
Let's make beaten egg for tonkatsu.
Crack the egg into a bowl.
Place a half of the egg into a tray.
Add water and mix it well.
Let's prepare the pork loin for tonkatsu.
Sprinkle salt and pepper on the pork.
Flip it over, and sprinkle salt and pepper.
Make cuts along the stringy parts of the pork.
Flip it over, and repeat the same procedure again.
Coat both sides of the pork with flour.
Shake off excess flour.
Next, dip it in the beaten egg.
Finally, coat with the panko breadcrumbs.
Let's cook the pork loin.
Check if the oil is hot enough.
Gently place the pork in oil and deep-fry it for two or three minutes at a medium heat.
Flip it over, and cook the other side for two or three minutes again.
Rotate the pork to brown uniformly.
Take out the tonkatsu, deep-fried pork, and place it on kitchen paper.
Cut the tonkatsu into one-inch pieces.
Serve the steamed rice on a plate.
Line up the tonkatsu on the rice.
Serve the curry on it.
Crispy texture of the tonkatsu goes great with spicy vegetable curry.
Fukujinzuke and rakkyo (Chinese onion) are often used as relishes for Japanese curry.
This recipe needs lots of ingredients, but I hope you try it yourself.
Good luck in the kitchen!
